text.p: Here are highlights from Polish newspapers this morning:
FRONT PAGE POLITICAL NEWS
DZIENNIK PRAWA I GOSPODARKI
- Poland and Spain are planning to form especially close economic relations, Poland's Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz said at meeting with Spanish businesspeople in Madrid yesterday.
ECONOMIC AND MARKET STORIES
RZECZPOSPOLITA
- The government's tax bill has provisions which hurt the taxpayer as well as Poland's economic foundations, the Polish Chamber of Commerce (KIG) president Andrzej Arendarski said.

- Telekomunikacja Polska SA (TPSA), Poland's state-owned telecoms firm, Telekom Finland, Centertel, Ericsson, Alcatel and a law firm have acquired tender documents they need to bid for the DCS 1800 digital mobile telephone operator licence.
- Poland's economic ministers committee (KERM) has given the green light to the coke industry restructuring programme.

- The Weglokoks SA coal trading firm was Poland's biggest exporter in 1996 with export sales reaching $890 million, a ranking produced by BOSS news agency showed. The KGHM copper conglomerate was second with exports worth $785 million.
- The listed Wielkopolski Bank Kredytowy (WBK) bank will be invited to buy the Komunalny Bank Spoldzielczy (KBS) cooperative bank, KBS cooperative members decided.

- The TU Europa SA insurance firm in Wroclaw, south-western Poland, will shortly present a share issue prospectus to the Polish Securities Commission (KPW). The company plans to increase its share capital by 2.0 million zlotys through an F-series issue of 500,000 shares priced at 4.0 zlotys per share, TU Europa's president Leszek Czarnecki said. It now has 0.4 percent market share in Poland's non-life market.

- The board of Bank Energetyki (BEN) energy sector bank has accepted the resignation of its president, Louis Montmory, and appointed Slawomir Horbaczewski in his place. Horbaczewski will yet have to wait for the approval of the central bank chief.
- The general shareholders meeting of the Fortuna SA insurance firm has accepted the resignation of its president Rafal Longin Blachut and appointed Bernd Jansen to the post.
DZIENNIK PRAWA I GOSPODARKI

- Six Canadian motor industry firms including Beck Electric, Ventra Group Inc, Heimatite Manufacturing Inc., ABC Group, A.G. Simpson Ltd., and Bauer Industries are planning to start subsidiaries and joint ventures in Poland. The firms make vehicle parts for General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler.

- Poland's International Fast Food Corporation (IFFC), the Polish franchisee of the Burger King fast food chain and Burger King's mother company Grand Metropolitan haved agreed to open more than 100 restaurants around Poland in the next five years.
GAZETA WYBORCZA
- Polish investment goods' prices in the first quarter of 1997 grew by 3.3 percent compared with the same period the year before, a report by the Central Statistical Office (GUS) said.
PARKIET

- The Browar Malopolski Strzelec brewery has presented a share issue prospectus to the Securities Commission (KPW). The brewery plans to issue up to 8.2 million C-series shares nominally worth 1.0 zloty each.

- Bank Komunalny will not pay a dividend in the next two years due to a convertible bond issue which will push up significantly the future share value as profits will be invested in development, board member Mieczyslaw Halk said.
NOTE - Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
